loans.use: To buy candies, gum, cookies, pops, churros, juices, caramels and chocolates.

loans.name: Walter

texts.en:
Walter S. is a rice farmer in rural Salitre. He is part of the first Communal Bank in the new Mifex Rural Finance Program. All the members of the Resistencia Communal Bank are part of an Association of Rice Farmers in Salitre named Resistencia. They will use the microloans to prepare the land and cultivate rice on their farms. Because they form part of a communal bank, they are all each others guarantors for the loan. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the Resistencia Association are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many microfinance programs, but it is imperative for the communities Mifex works with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

Walter has been farming rice with his family his entire life. On his plot of land he also has some fruits such as papaya and pineapple. As a second source of income Walter raises cattle. He needs the loan because of the bad water situation in his land. He hopes he can invest in a good watering system in order to improve his production.

Loan Use and Repayment

The loans in this sector will be used to create water deposits that will prevent flooding in the case of heavy rains or store water in case of droughts. They will also be used to treat the land prior to farming, plant the seeds and purchase fertilizer. The loan repayment schedule is also different from the typical microentrepreneur. Because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures, Mifex asks them only to pay 50% of the capital in the first 6 months of the loan. The rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.

Below is more information about Salitre compiled by the staff at Mifex when evaluating the potential of the sector for the Rural Finance Program.

Economy of Salitre

Salitre is a rural area in the Province of Guayas which is known as the capital of Montuvios (montuvio is a cowboy) with approximately 30,000 inhabitants. The main economic activities are herding and agriculture, which make up about 80% of the economy. The infrastructure and basic services are poor, especially the roads and water services.

Salitre is highly dedicated to rice farming and cattle ranching. Rice is a crop that yields about every four months. In order to farm rice, the environment must be very humid and there must be a high volume of water. The lack of a structured water system makes it difficult for the small farmers to be highly productive. The best months for cultivating rice are early in the year during the rainy season on the coast of Ecuador.

Salitre is a national tourist attraction as many Ecuadorians visit the fresh water Salitre River. There are cottages, small restaurants and water attractions that people come to enjoy.

Access to Credit

There is not a single financial institution that provides services to the productive sector of the local economy. The only access to credit comes from loan sharks who charge extremely high interest rates averaging around 20% a month. The locals are also exploited by the intermediaries that buy their products in order to commercialize them in the city and to export abroad. These intermediaries buy crops in advance at very low prices, finance soil at extremely high prices and often provide emergency loans for even higher interest rates than the loan sharks.

Risks

Salitre is a dangerous area despite its rural location. There is a high incidence of robbery of cattle that results in the fact that many of the ranch owners owning weapons to protect their property. Because the police are not present in these areas, farmers and ranchers must apply their own laws and provide their own security. In some instances they have formed their own cooperatives and associations to have a community crime prevention force.

Salitre is in the lowlands of Ecuador and is vulnerable to flooding during the rainy season. In the event of a heavy rainy season, often at its worst when El Niño occurs, rice farmers lose many of their crops. All this is due to a lack of infrastructure in the area.

loans.use: Help improve his rice production

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Shamin

texts.en: “I have six children, four of whom are in school. I spend most of my day taking care of the children and housework. My husband used to work in the city and but his left that job to operate his own Rickshaw about four years ago. We now want to purchase a new Rickshaw (three wheeled vehicle) by pooling in some of our savings and now require a loan.” Shamin B., Pakistan

loans.use: Purchase a Rickshaw

loans.name: María

texts.es:
Maria V. is 22 years old: she has a partner and one two-year old son. She owns a hairdresser’s shop that has a well-established clientele, as it’s located in a very commercial zone which a lot of people pass through. Maria also sells clothes that she buys abroad, travelling to Argentina to purchase them. Her boyfriend is 24 years old and helps with the clothes sales as a travelling salesperson. They live in a rented house, and are a hard-working and respectable family. The loan will be used to buy merchandise in order to increase the clothes-shop’s stock: blouses, jeans, t-shirts, belts and other accessories. They hope that in the future they will be able to own their own house, and for this they are saving the profits that both businesses are generating.

Translated from the Spanish by Katy Long, Kiva Volunteer

La Sra. María V. tiene 22 años, esta concubinada, tiene 1 hijo de dos años de edad. Posee una peluquería en la cual cuenta con una clientela bien formada, pues se encuentra en una zona muy comercial donde transita mucha gente. María también se dedica a la venta de ropas que compra del exteriror, viajando a la Argentina para adquirirlos. Su pareja tiene 24 años y le ayuda con las ventas de las ropas en forma ambulante. Viven en una casa alquilada. Es una familia muy trabajadora y honrada. El Crédito destinará para la compra de mercaderías para así poder ampliar el stock de su ropería; tales como blusas, jeans, remeras, cintos y otros artículos de bijouterie. Desean en el futuro poder adquirir una casa propia, para ello ya están ahorrando de las ganancias que genera ambos negocios.

loans.use: Buying spring-summer season garments

loans.name: Ni Luh Sutamiasih

texts.id:
Ni Luh Sutamiasih makes and sells "Red Sugar." She obtains the ingredients from her husband, Ketut Kicen who seeks coconut honey for her to process. She obtains the ingredients from her small coconut plantation, and she also buys some coconut honey from her neighbor. She makes the "red sugar" at home. After all ingredients are combined in a pot, it was heated to concentrate the mixture. Then it was placed on a cast and cooled. Then the red sugar was ready. Besides producing her own "Red sugar," Ni Luh Sutamiasih buys "red sugar" from her neighbors too to be resold to wholesaler. To increase her red sugar dealing, Ni Luh Sutamiasih joined DINARI, where she expected to obtain funding and training assistance. She earns about $33 in revenue and gets about $3 profit. She hopes to be able to support her three children with the additional income from the business.

Translated from Indonesian by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunteer

Membuat gula merah adalah menjadi pekerjaan sehari - hari bagi Ni Luh Sutamiasih. Bahan baku didapat dari suaminya, Ketut Kicen, yang setiap hari mencari tuak kelapa ( sari dari bunga pohon kelapa ) yang sebagai bahan dasar . Bahan didapat dari kebun kelapa miliknya, dan didapat dengan bekerja sama dengan pemilik pohon kelapa langganannnya yang sudah biasa diambil tuaknya. Proses pembuatan gula merah dilakukan sendiri dirumahnya. Setelah bahan baku dikumpulkan dalam satu wadah, kemudian dipanaskan sampai mengental, setelah pada kepekatan tertentu kemudian adonan tersebut di letakan pada sebuah cetakan dan dibiarkan sampai dingin , jadilah gula merah dan siap untuk di perjualbelikan Selain membuat gula merah sendiri, Ni Luh Sutamiasih setiap hari berkeliling kepada masyarakat untuk membeli gula merah. Untuk menambah modal usaha berjual beli gula merah Ni Luh Sutamiasih bergabung dengan DINARI . Selain mendapat modal Ni Luh Sutaiasih juga mendapat pembinaan. Pendapatan setiap harinya dapat mencapai Rp. 300.000,- dengan keuntungan bersih mencapai Rp.30.000,-. Dengan hasih jerih payahnya itu Ni Luh Sutamiasih dapat membiaya ketiga anaknya, dan dipakai untuk keperluan setip harinya.

loans.use: Purchase "red sugar" from farmers to be resold

loans.name: Ricardo

texts.es:
Ricardo is a young entrepreneur who at age 27 already owns two commercial stands in the municipal market where he sells vegetables.

He started as a longshoreman and as a helper for others that had commercial stands at the same market; he saved some money and after receiving a good offer he was able to buy his own stand.

His business has gone well, and as such he was able to buy another stand, which is attended by his brother. They open every day from 2 am till 5 pm, and he sells all sorts of vegetables such as tomatoes, lettuce, onions, etc.

He is requesting a loan so that he can buy merchandise in bigger quantities, as in this time of the year when a greater amoung of the sales take place.

Translated from Spanish by Samantha, Kiva Volunteer.

Ricardo es un hombre joven y emprendedor, con tal solo 27 años el ya es dueño de dos puestos de ventas de verduras en el mercado municipal de la ciudad.

Empezó como estibador y ayudante de unos señores que también poseían locales de ventas de verduras en ese mismo mercado; junto unos ahorros y luego de recibir una buena oferta, Ricardo se animó a comprar un puesto de ventas con algunas mercaderías.

Cuenta que le va bien y que gracias a las ganancias que le genero su primer puesto, adquirió otro más que es atendido por su hermano. Abre todos los días a las 2 a.m. hasta las 5 p.m. Vende todo tipo de verduras como tomates, morrones, lechugas, cebollas, etc.

Solicita el crédito para adquirir mercaderías en grandes cantidades, ya que en esta época del año es cuando se registran mayor cantidad de ventas.

loans.use: To buy merchandise such as tomatoes, onions, lettuce, carrots, red peppers.

loans.name: Urinova

texts.en: Urinova M. lives in Spitamen, Tajikistan. She is married and has 5 children. She has been the client of MicroInvest since 2007. She has recommended herself as a reliable client who trusts the MicroInvest loan procedures. Her business stability and income increase helped her to return a previous loan and to improve her business situation. Mrs. Urinova is experienced in the business of livestock. She has the appropriate knowledge in  livestock because she has been engaged with livestock from the early years when she helped first her mother on the farm looking after cows and sheep  and then working with her husband. It is the family business that brings the general income. She is engaged in livestock raising and selling and milk production . In time she dreams of  purchasing a pedigree a milk cow  that would ensure the milk products making and selling. Now Mrs. Urinova requests a loan of $300 for  business development that would permit her to increase significantly the family income allow her to purchase a milk cow . It would permit her to ensure the good future of her children.

loans.use: for business development

loans.name: Kitomondo Group

texts.en: Hawa, Zaina, Ashura and Judith are married and have 2 ,1 ,1 and 2 children respectively. They plan to use their Kiva loan to start a clothing business.

loans.use: To start a new business

loans.name: Murod

texts.ru:
Murod G. works as the chairman of the farming collective “Malikabonu.” He is married and has 5 children. He has been growing livestock for 18 years. His wife, Hurmatoy, and his sons help him in his work. Murod raises animal feed on the fields of the collective and stores it for the winter. He would like to use his loan to purchase several heads of livestock thereby expanding his livestock count.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

Гаппаров Мурод Сатторович - работает председателем дехканского хозяйства «Маликабону». Женат , имеет 5 детей. Откормом скота занимается более 18 лет. Ему помогают жена Хурматой и сыновия. На полях дехканского хозяйства он выращивает корм и запасает на зимний период. На получаемый кредит он хочет купить несколько голов крупно рогатого скота тем самим увеличить количество скота.

loans.use: Purchase livestock

loans.name: Chanlach

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanlach H., 48, and her husband married in 1978. They have nine children; six sons and three daughters. Two of their children are married and live outside the family home. One of their children weaves silk at home, two are employed full time and the other four are students. The family lives on an island on the Mekong River about twelve kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Chanlach has been a silk weaver for over ten years. It’s a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village who will then sell them in Phnom Penh. Her family has two looms. Her husband is a worker. 

She is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase materials for weaving silk.

loans.use: to purchase materials for weaving silk

loans.name: Charlotte

texts.en:
E. Charlotte sells food. She is married and has 4 children. Her business is doing very well, and she wants to increase sales. She is running out of goods to sell.
She is a requesting a loan to buy more food to sell.

loans.use: To buy more food to sell

loans.name: Gulbahor

texts.en:
B. Gulbahor is 40 years old. She is married and is the loving mother of three adorable children. Her husband is a teacher. The income of her husband was not enough for the family expenses, so Gulbahor decided to open her own business. She began three years ago selling footwear.

Her elder son Daler helps her with the business. He is pictured in the photo. Together with her son, they are traveling to the neighboring country Kyrgyzstan, Bishkek city, to purchase new goods for wholesale prices. Her business allows Gulbahor to support her family. Gulbahor is working hard to keep her children satisfied and to give them the best future.

Today she requests a loan of 950 $ US Dollars as she is planning to expand her business and to improve her family budget. Gulbahor promises to pay the loan in 10 months and expresses her gratitude to everyone who trusts her and is supporting her. Let’s support this brave and selfless woman.

loans.use: Purchasing new goods for expanding the business.

loans.name: Esi

texts.en: Esi O., who is married and has three children, sells smoked fish. Unfortunaely, her husband's income from fishing is not sufficient for the family. She wants additional capital to expand her business to meet the high demand for her goods and to increase her profits.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business.

loans.name: Chhum

texts.en:
Chhum S., 46, operates a motor-taxi service in Dangkao, where he lives with his wife, Sok Phinin, and their three children. Two of his children are younger and still in school, while one of his sons works in construction and helps support the family with his US$ 2 per day income.

Chhum S.'s motor-taxi service typically generates US$ 4 each day in income, while his wife sells a Vietnamese noodle dish called "Ban Srung" and typically makes US$ 4 each day as well.

Chhum S. has asked for a loan of US$ 1000 to open up a cafe for his wife. He would like to purchase some equipment to make coffee and create a more permanent stall where his wife can sell her noodles. He believes that there is great customer demand for his wife's dish and that she can expand her customer base through this investment.

loans.use: Purchase equipment to open up a cafe

loans.name: Irshad Rani's Group

texts.en:
Irshad rani baji is the wife of B. M. and lives in the city named Lahore, in a district called named Walton, Pakistan. She has been married for the last 25 years. She is the mother of five children: four boys and one girl.

Irshad baji's brother has a cigarette shop. Her elder son works with her brother. The next eldest is in 10th standard. The one after him works in a factory. Her younger son wants to be a tailor. Her daughter completed her 10th standard and presently she is free and does household work.

Irshad baji's husband is a daily wage laborer. Irshad baji is a housewife and prefers to do household work. She has successfully repaid her three loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy more cigarettes for her brother's cigarette shop.

She is joined in her loan group by several more members. Mumtaz baji wants a loan to buy wood for her shutter business. Nasreen baji wants a loan to buy cosmetics for her beauty parlor. Bashiran baji wants a loan to repair her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled vehicle). Nasreen and Shabnam baji each want a loan to buy spare parts for vehicles.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy cigarettes to re-sell

loans.name: Ndifon

texts.en:
S. is 45 years old and married to Joseph Nfona. 

She sells Koki pudding, which is made up of ground beans mixed with red oil and salt; this is eaten with boiled plantains, coco yams, potatoes, and cassava. This is a very delicious meal that many inhabitants in the community love eating. Palm wine is a drink gotten from Palms and is white in colour. It is usually called "White mimbo".

S.'s life has been especially difficult because her child has been ill and she hasn't been able to take her to the hospital because S. hasn't been able to pay the fees. Faced with this illness, S. joined GHAPE in order to improve her living standards. She is a hard-working woman who has acquired many business and management techniques from GHAPE.

loans.use: To buy ingredients

loans.name: Nueva Esperanza Group

texts.es:
Comité Nueva Esperanza, así se denomina el comité integrado por 21 mujeres del Asentamiento Nueva Esperanza de la Ciudad de Itá. Este grupo se conformó gracias a que la actual presidenta, Nancy S., se acercó a la asesora en una reunión que la misma tenía en la zona, para averiguar acerca del Programa del Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras, la misma quedó muy entusiasmada y logró conformar su grupo en fecha 02 de julio del 2008 con 21 mujeres, quienes se encuentran muy contentas trabajando con este programa.

Las integrantes de este grupo destinan su crédito a diferentes actividades tales como:

1) Nancy S.. Confección y venta de ropas artesanales.

2) María M.. Venta de lencerías y perfumes.

3) Mirian Chávez. Venta de frutas y verduras.

4) Elvira Álvarez. Venta de plantas.

5) Claudia Cáceres. Venta de comidas y reciclajes.

6) Rosa O.. Compra y venta de reciclajes y huesos.

7) Lorenza F.. Despensa.

8) Teresa L.. Venta de mercerías.

9) María D.. Venta de comidas.

10) Apolonia E..Venta de frutas y verduras.

11) Francisca Brítez. Venta de ropas.

12) Lidia S.. Despensa.

13) Liliana M.. Venta de zapatos.

14) Aida S.. Venta de frutas y remedios refrescantes.

15) Saturnina Benítez. Venta de carnes.

16) María Benítez. Venta de comidas.

17) María R.. Reciclajes.

18) Celsa Jiménez. Venta de frutas.

19) Yohana V.. Venta de ropas artesanales.

20) Magdalena R.. Venta de comidas.

21) Sara L.. Cría de chanchos y gallinas.

Todas las integrantes del grupo demuestran compañerismo y solidaridad, asisten a las reuniones semanales y realizan actividades para recaudar fondos para el bien común del grupo.

Desean adquirir con sus créditos materiales para la confección de ropas artesanales, compra de materiales reciclados y huesos, compra de frutas y verduras, compra de ingredientes para la preparación de comidas, compras de lencerías y perfumes, compra de plantas, compra de zapatos, compra de mercerías, compra de carnes, compra de ropas, compra de mercaderías para la despensa y cría de chanchos y gallinas.
texts.en:
The Nueva Esperanza (New Hope) Committee is made up of 21 women of Asentamiento Nueva Esperanza in the city of Itá. This group was created because the current president Nancy S. was approached by a counselor in a meeting to find out about the Program of the Committee of Enterprising Women. Nancy was very enthusiastic and succeeded in making her group on July 2, 2008 with 21 women, who are very happy to be working with this program. The members of this group will use their loan for different activities including the following:

1. Nancy S.. To make and sell traditional clothes. 2. María M.. To sell undergarments and perfumes. 3. Mirian Chávez. To sell fruits and vegetables. 4. Elvira Álvarez. To sell plants. 5. Claudia Cáceres. To sell food and recycling. 6. Rosa O.. To buy and sell recycling and bones. 7. Lorenza F.. Larder. 8. Teresa L.. Haberdashery. 9. María D.. To sell food. 10. Apolonia E.. To sell fruits and vegetables. 11. Francisca Brítez. To sell clothes. 12. Lidia S.. Larder. 13. Liliana M.. To sell shoes. 14. Aida S.. To sell fruits and refreshing cures. 15. Saturnina Benítez. To sell meats. 16. María Benítez. To sell food. 17. María R.. Recycling. 18. Celsa Jiménez. To sell fruits. 19. Yohana V.. To sell traditional clothes. 20. Magdalena R.. To sell food. 21. Sara L.. To raise pigs and hens.

All the members of the group show companionship and solidarity. They attend weekly meetings and pursue activities to collect funds for the common good of the group. With their loans, they want to acquire materials to make traditional clothing, to buy recycled materials and bones, fruits and vegetables, ingredients to make food, undergarments and perfumes, plants, shoes, merchandise for the haberdashery, meats, clothes, merchandise for the larder, and to raise pigs and hens.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy varied merchandise

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase drugs to stock the pharmacy

loans.name: Dorotea

texts.es:
La Señora Dorotea Gómez tiene la edad de 60 años su estado civil es soltera, Doña Dorotea tiene 5 hijos de los cuales ninguno de sus hijos dependen de ella, sus propósitos son de mantener su negocio activo para lograr sus objetivos ya que necesita salir adelante con su negocio por lo que este le permitió sacar a sus hijos adelante para que estos fueran hombres y mujeres de provecho, su deseo es proporcionarle  a su vivienda las comodidades necesarias ya que quiere remodelarla completamente para que el día de mañana pueda permanecer en ella para su vejes y no tenga que estar en dependencia de sus hijos.


Su actividad económica es la venta de comida como lo es: arroz, frijoles, maduro, queso frito, queso, plátanos y papas, el tiempo que tiene de poseer este negocio es de 20 años la ubicación es la siguiente de la iglesia católica 2 cuadras al sur, ella comienza este negocio por cuenta propia y empieza a realizar prestamos con Fundación León 2000 y decide establecer un negocio en su casa de habitación y realizaba viajes hasta Matagalpa para la compra de queso, leche pero no pudo mantener este negocio y por eso que mas tarde decide implementar el negocio de venta de comida y así obtiene este negocio, el financiamiento es para capital de trabajosa que tiene que realizar las respectivas compras para la elaboración de sus productos.
texts.en:
Dorotea Gomex is 60 years old and is single. She has 5 children none of whom depend on her. Her intention is to keep her business active in order to accomplish her objectives as she needs to be successful with her business. Her business allowed her to get her children ahead so that they could be useful men and women. Her wish is to provide her home with the necessary comforts. She wants completely remodel it so that in the future she can remain in it through her old age and not have to depend on her children. Dorotea's economic activity is the sale of food such as rice, beans, fried cheese, cheese, bananas and potatoes. She has had her business for 20 years and it was located next to the catholic church. She started her business on her own and started receiving loans from Fundacion Leon 2000 and then decided to establish the business in her home. She had to travel to Matagalpa to buy cheese and milk but she was not able to maintain this business which is why she later decided to establish her current business selling food. The loan she is requesting will be used as working capital to purchase the respective products she needs to make her food.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Manzo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital to purchase products to make her food.

loans.name: Lach

texts.en: Lach P., 55, is married and lives with her husband and her child in the province of Siem Reap. She and her husband together have a business of catching and then selling fish at the market to earn approximately US$7 in net income per day. Mrs. Lach P. is asking for a loan to purchase a wooden boat and fishing nets for her husband.

loans.use: To purchase fishing tools.

loans.name: Elsavar

texts.en: Elsavar was born in 1987. He is single and lives in Baku city. This young man has run his general store for three years. Now he needs a loan of 950 AZN to buy foodstuffs for improving his business.

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Lailanie

texts.en:
Lailanie P. is 36 years old, and married to Ferdinand who is a 38 year old farmer. They are blessed with four children, namely: Felmie - 15 years old, third year high school; Delenger - 13 years old, first year high school; and Kenneth - 9 years old and Fredick 8 years old, who are both elementary students. Lailanie loves her family very much and she keeps doing what is best for them, especially for her children. She hopes to send them to college for them to have a better future.  

Lailanie retail sells rice in their village of Sitio Anguapan. She wishes to receive a loan amounting to PHP3,000 to use as additional capital for her existing business to improve her rice vending. "Adding at least 100 kilos of rice will be of great help," said Lailanie. She is working hard to improve the business and be able to maintain it for a long period of time for her children’s education. The business is only 6 months old and she hopes that it will grow soon.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Toyin

texts.en: Toyin is 35 years old and married with five children. She sells bricks. She needs the loan amount of N 140,000 to purchase more bags of cement and sand to make more bricks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of cement and sand to make more bricks to sell

loans.name: Wajiha

texts.en:
About three years ago, Wajiha S. was rather desperate and took it upon herself to start a business. In particular, she and her husband had mounting costs of living and looming expenses for their children's education (they have four school-age children). As a result, she decided to open a small grocery store, which she has seen steadily grow because of her hard work and effort.

She is now requesting a loan in the amount of $1,000 to buy more merchandise such as sweet bread, beverages, rice, pasta, vegetables, and fruit. With your help, she will be able to continue to improve her operation and to thereby satisfy her family's living expenses.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional merchandise

loans.name: Monita

texts.en:
Monita C. grew up on a farm. Her parents, her siblings as well as her friends are farmers. She also married a farmer, Rosendo C.. Farming is a common livelihood in the Philippines. She is into this business to ensure food for the family.

The purpose of her loan is for fertilizers and seeds. She is also interested to look for some possible income areas to help more in the family earnings.

CEVI provides loans, training and insurance coverage to Monita and the rest of its clients.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and herbicides for farming.

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.en:
Dorcas D. is twenty-nine years old. She is married and has two children. She owns and operates a beauty and Rasta hairdo salon in her neighborhood.

Dorcas is very skilled. She is a talented hairdresser who adds a lot of beauty to the hair of her many customers. That is her secret. Dorcas uses weavons and meshes to plait her clients' hair to add beauty to them. She has been in hairdressing business for seven years.

Because she believes in efficiency and effectiveness of service, she wants to use the loan to buy larger quantities of hair products like weavons, mesh, threads etc. to avoid shortage and poor service. She has three apprentices training under her. She belongs to the village bank called "Noble ladies."

loans.use: To buy larger quantities of hair products

loans.name: Ros

texts.en:
Mrs. Ros, 55, and her husband, Mr. Then Tep, 52, live along National Road Number One about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They were married in 1981 and have four children: one son and three daughters. All of the children are married, but two of her daughters live in the family home.

Ros has been selling flowers for 20 years; she buys thE. from farmers in her village for resale in the market in Phnom Penh. She is able to receive gross profit of about $10 to $12.50 per week. Mr. Then Tep has been driving a remoque taxi (a motorbike with a trailer at the back) for over seven years. 

Ros is applying for her first loan of $500 to purchase a motorcycle for her children to commute to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her children to commute to work

loans.name: Modisola

texts.en: Modisola sells clothes and shoes. Modisola is 30 years old and married without a child. She hopes for a loan of N50, 000 to purchase more shoes and clothes to sell. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and shoes

loans.name: Anthony

texts.en: Anthony is twenty-three years old and married with two children, ages six and two.  Anthony wants this loan so he can join his older brother in the business of selling shoes. His brother will take him to Nairobi, where he can buy new men’s and women’s shoes. Then he will return to Kisumu, where he can sell the shoes at the main bus station, and at the market on Sundays.  If he is successful with this business, Anthony will expand to other clothing options in addition to shoe sales.

loans.use: To buy a stock of shoes to sell

loans.name: Ludivina

texts.en:
Mrs Ludivina D., 38, is a resident of P4 Gango, Ozamiz City. She is married to Roel D., a construction worker, and they are blessed with four children. One of her children is in high school, two are in elementary school, and the other is an infant. In order to help her husband support the family, Ludivina set up a business selling fruit and vegetables two years ago with an initial capital of only 1,000 PHP. Now, her business has grown bigger and she is earning an average net income of 5,000 PHP a month from her sales.

Ludivina joined Kiva partner, PMPC, in September 2007, and her membership has proved very helpful to her as she has been able to avail herself of the cooperative's products and benefits. Now on her third loan cycle, she is applying for a loan of 10,000 PHP to add to her existing fruit and vegetable business. Her only dream in life is to give her children a better future and be able to expand her business some day.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her fruit and vegetable business

loans.name: Tohir

texts.en:
At the age of 19, Tohir is now very responsible for his family. He is a hard-working person and he knows how every cent is spent in his business. With his desire to become a successful farmer in the future, Tohir is requesting a loan of 5000 Somoni to sustain the potato field entrusted to him by his father. Sometimes he is able to use the income from his business to extend financial assistance to his younger sister, who is currently studying. Tohir believes that by being an industrious person, he can become successful like other farmers in his village. He is proud of his choice and is really working hard to sustain and improve his farm.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchase seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Bintou

texts.fr: Bintou S. est une femme de 40 ans, elle est mariée et a en charge 4 enfants. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de Vélingara Ouest2 depuis le 06 mai 2003 et y a contracté 12 prêts qu'elle a toujours remboursés sans difficulté. Avec ce prêt elle développe une activité de vente sur table de légumes, de fruits, de maïs et divers produits alimentaires. Avec les bénéfices de son commerce elle soutien son mari pour la nourriture, la santé et l'amélioration des conditions de vie de la famille. Elle rembourse son prêt globalement au bout de 6 mois.

loans.use: Faire la promotion de son activité

loans.name: Easter Group

texts.en:
These are small scale businesswomen in the northern city of Makeni. They have come to SMT for the very first time to seek a loan of Le 500,000 for each to enable them expand their businesses. With a loan of Le 500,000, they will be able to add more stocks into their businesses, make more sales, and more profit. Consequently, they will be able to improve their standard of living by sending their children to school, feed and clothe them. 

Kadiatu C. (right) is the leader of this group. She was born in Makeni, thirty-two years ago. She is married to a businessman and they have two children. One of his children is in class III and the other is still not of school going age.  Kadiatu sells slippers and dishes. She has been in this business since childhood days. Kadiatu will invest Le 200,000 of this loan into her slippers business and the remainder she will use to buy more dishes.

loans.use: Invest in her business

loans.name: Bella Amistad Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal BelL. Amistad inicia su primer ciclo con  24 socias.
Las socias realizan diferentes negocios como L. venta D. comidas, abarrotes en general, medicina natural, leña, repuestos, comida, jugos, ropa, bebidas, también brindan servicio D. transporte D. pasajeros, servicio mecánico D. carros.
Sus ventas los realizan D. manera ambulatoria, en sus casas, en locales alquilados, D. casa en casa.
Las socias necesitan diferentes montos D. prestamos como 300 soles, 600 soles, 1050 soles haciendo un total D. 12150 soles en prestamos en el Banco Comunal.
Sus prestamos serán invertidos en L. compra D. leña, carne, arroz, azúcar, medicina natural, repuestos, ropa, frutas, bebidas.
Los sueños D. las socias son ampliar sus negocios, tener casa propia, local estable, brindar una buena educación a sus hijos para que sean profesionales.
texts.en:
The "BelL. Amistad" (Beautiful Friendship) Comunal Bank began its first cycle with 24 members. The members have different businesses such as selling food, general groceries, natural medicine, firewood, spare parts, juice, clothing, and drinks. They also proviD. passenger transport services and auto mechanic services.

They conduct their sales in an traveling manner, in their homes, in rented premises, and from house to house. The members need different loan amounts such as 300 Peruvian soles, 600 soles, and 1,050 soles, for a total of 12,150 soles that the comunal bank is borrowing.

Their loans will be used to buy firewood, meat, rice, sugar, natural medicine, spare parts, clothing, fruit, and drinks. The members dream of expanding their businesses, having their own homes and a fixed location to do business, and providing a good education for their children so that they may become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Sindewald, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy firewood, meat, rice, sugar, natural medicine, spare parts, clothing, food, and drinks

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase sacks of flour and charcoal as well as local beverages

loans.name: Rios De Agua Viva Group

texts.es:
En uno de los Centros Focales de Pro Mujer, “Los Andes” se encuentra la Asociación Comunal “Rios de agua viva”, con aproximadamente 2 años de vida, cuenta con 12 integrantes que en su mayoría se dedican al tejido de mantas  y venta de comida, pocas se dedican a la elaboración de tarjetas,  confección de chamarras, producción de cotillones y venta de repuesto de auto, ellas indican que necesitan  el préstamo para la compra de materia prima que les permita elaborar sus productos, como lana, tela y otras para comprar mercadería.

Este grupo tiene como líderes a Olga E. como la presidenta, Mery M. es la Tesorera y Guadalupe Q. es la Secretaria de Actas. A todas les gusta participar en las reuniones así como en las capacitaciones.
texts.en:
The community bank group "Rios De Agua Viva" ("Rivers of Life Water") is based out of one of the regional offices of Kiva partner Pro Mujer near the Andes. The group has about two years' experience, and the majority of the 12 members make a living weaving blankets and selling food. A few others dedicate themselves to making cards, sewing jackets, producing party favors or selling spare auto parts. The members are in need of the loan so they can purchase the supplies they need to make their products, such as wool and fabric, while other plan to use the loan to purchase merchandise. The leader of this group is president Olga E., Mery M. is the treasurer and Guadalupe Q. is the secretary. All the members enjoy participating in their meetings as well as the training sessions.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase supplies and merchandise

loans.name: Porcita

texts.en:
Porcita A. lives in the village of Sto. Niño, Tukuran Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 45 years old, married and has five grown children. She runs a store where she sells products people use daily, such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste. Porcita has been in this business for more than five years and earns about 4,000 PHP a month from her work.

Last year, Porcita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and ability to engage in business. Porcita has successfully repaid two previous loans from GDMPC. She used those loans to buy additional products to sell, and has applied for a new loan to continue to secure more items to sell to her customers. She will use the additional revenue made possible by this loan to improve her living conditions. 

About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to expand her business

location.town: Sto. Niño, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur

loans.name: Rachael

texts.en: Rachael is 30 is years old, married and has 3 children. Her husband is a policeman and also supports the household.  She sells cooking oil, snails, and coconut to make a living. With these combined businesses, she is able to meet the basic needs and necessities of her family members. The demand for her cooking oil is high because it is an essential ingredient in the preparation of Nigerian foods.  She hopes for a loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more cooking oil to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Famous Group

texts.en: Josephine is 38 years old. She is divorced and has given birth to two children, both in school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in a tourist attraction community in the central region of Ghana. The community is one of the coastal towns in the country. As a result, the major occupation of the people is fishing. Josephine trades in printed fabrics. She is the leader of a trust bank group called Famous. The members of the group are mainly into fishing and other commercial activities. They request a loan to procure goods in bulk to expand their businesses. It is their desire to give their children the best education they can afford. Josephine is in the middle of the photograph.

loans.use: To buy stock

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en:
Maricel R. is from the village of Poblacion Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental. She is 43 years old. Maricel is separated from her spouse and has one young child. To make a living, Maricel sells office supplies like bond paper, pencils, ballpoint pens, and cartolina in her local community. Maricel has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 15000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Maricel joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maricel is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Maricel from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional writing supplies to sell.

loans.name: Houma

texts.fr: Houma B., 51 ans, est du Banc Villageois de GADAPARA depuis 5 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 02 enfants. Elle fait de la transformation et vente de pâte d'arachide, elle vend également des graines d'arachide et des tissus. Son objectif est de participer à l'amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille et de renforcer son niveau d'épargne.
texts.en:
Houma B., 51 years old, has been with the Banc Villageois of Gadapara for five years. She is married and the mother of two children. She makes and sells peanut-butter, she also sells groundnuts and fabric. Her goal is to contribute to the improvement of her family's quality of life and to strengthen her savings.

Translated from French by Carolyn McMahon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Strengthen her investment capital

loans.name: Brigitte

texts.en:
Brigitte is 45 years old, and she is married with 9 children who are aged between 4 and 18 years old. Brigitte and her family live in Nyamagabe, a region of the southern province of Rwanda. Here, Brigitte owns a business selling peas, and this is her third successful year in this business. Brigitte starts at 7 AM in the morning and works until 5 PM every day. Brigitte is really dedicated to this business because it helps her to feed her family.

After 3 years of experience in this business, Brigitte has a number of customers greater than the quantity of peas she can sell to them. To satisfy the needs of her customers, Brigitte wants to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company. With this loan, her hope is to satisfy the demand of her customers. If she can do that, of course the profits will increase. With those profits, one portion will be used in building a secure future for her family and another portion will be used for reinvestment into her business.

loans.use: A large quantity of peas for sale

loans.name: Teresita Pee Group

texts.en:
Teresita P. is from the village of Calube, Aloran. She is 47 years old and is the group leader of a three-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Teresita is married and has one school-aged child. She owns and operates a business running a food stall, selling rice products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

In 2005, Teresita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital.

Teresita is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 6th cycle from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 


About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her  food business

loans.name: Soen Phy Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Soen P. is the village bank president for a 13-member group loan offered by Kiva partner, AMK. The group members are located in Chey Chumneah village in Kandal province and will use their loans to purchase equipment, supplies and other items for different purposes.
Mrs. Soen P. and her husband, Kol Phon, are farmers who rent a 1.5-hectare field for farming. They now face a problem because they do not have enough money to support their farm. Therefore, Mrs. Soen P. has decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticide to support her crops. The couple has four children – two are seamstresses in a garment factory, one is a farmer, while the other is a student and helps in the family's farming business.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: José Alberto

texts.es: José Alberto M. T. es un hombre trabajador que se preocupara por el bienestar de su familia, el adquirió una vivienda de interés social ya hace años y le ha hecho mejoras con ahorros propios para ofrecerles a sus hijos confort y un patrimonio seguro para cuando ello crezcan. Desde que adquirió la vivienda al techo no le ha puesto impermeabilizante y teme que en temporada de lluvia se pueda trasminar el agua, por este motivo el pide el apoyo para poder realizar su proyecto y para esto necesita comprar material para su proyecto.
texts.en:
José Alberto M. T. is a hard-working man who worries about his family’s well-being. Years ago he got a house through social services. He used his own savings to make improvements in order to give his children comfort and a secure inheritance when they are grown. Since he got the house the roof has not been waterproofed. He is afraid that that it will leak during the rainy season. That is why he is asking for help to be able to complete his project. In order to do so he needs to buy material for his project.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Waterproof his house

loans.name: Francisco Javier

texts.es:
El señor Francisco Javier V. P.  es trabajador de la Alcaldía de Chinandega se desempeña como vigilante habita en el barrio  Julio Cesar Tinoco, tiene cuatro hijos a cargo,  es casado y su señora se dedica a la venta de verduras  ambulante.

El señor Francisco Javier V. P.  solicito el crédito para mejorar su vivienda, lleva ya dos años trabajando con CEPRODEL  y ha sido muy responsable con sus pagos.
texts.en:
Mr. Francisco Javier works for the mayor's office in Chinandega as a night watchman and lives in the Julio César Tinoco barrio. He has 4 children in his charge, is married, and his wife sells vegetables as a street vendor. Francisco Javier is requesting a loan for home improvement. He has worked with CEPRODEL for 2 years and has been very responsible with his payments.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: BUYING WOOD AND ZINC SHEETS FOR HOME IMPROVEMENTS

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty S. is from the village of Rizal, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 50 years old. Betty is married and has four adult children. To make a living, Betty operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling vegetables, like cabbage, string beans, cucumber, etc., in the public market. Betty has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2009, Betty joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Betty has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Betty is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used purchase additional goods for sale. This will be the third loan taken out by Betty from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase additional goods for sale

loans.name: Leoncio

texts.es:
Nuestro socio pertenece al banco comunal “PACAHA ILLARIY”; Nuestro socio vive en la comunidad de Llullucha,  distrito de Ocongate,  provincia de Quispicanchis departamento de Cusco.

Nuestro socio es él  Sr. Leoncio,  él socio tiene 35 años de edad es conviviente y tiene 3 hijos y él trabaja como porteador en el camino inka y cuando no está en camino inka él es albañil; Nuestro socio solicita el préstamo para comprarse mochila para sus viajes y zapatos.

El soco agradece y valora el apoyo brindado mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de su deuda en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
This member belongs to the communal bank "Pacaha Illariy". He lives in the community of Llullucha, Ocongate district, Quispicanchis province, Cusco department. His name is Leoncio. He is 35 years old and lives with his girlfriend and three children. He works as a porter on the Inca Road, and when he's not on the road he works as a mason. He is seeking this loan to buy a backpack for his travels and shoes. He is grateful for the support from this loan and is committed to making his payments on time.

Translated from Spanish by Trisha Bury, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase backpack for traveling and shoes

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice H is currently in the business of selling bags of shorgum and maize at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of maize to sell.  Alice is 49 years old and is widowed.   She has six children. Her children do not go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan she hopes to be able to build a house for rent.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services. These programs are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more bags of maize to sell

loans.name: Mwanamkasi

texts.en: Mwanamkasi H. has been operating her food stall for the last two years. She sells at an open air market nearby her home where neighbors and passersby are mainly her customers. Mwanamkasi is happily married with three children, two boys and a girl, all of whom attend school. Her husband is a taxi driver and supports the family and their daily basic needs. They rent a home with no electricity nor piped water. Mwanamkas is requesting a loan of Ksh 40,000 to purchase 250kgs of Irish potatoes, baking flour, cooking oil and one sack of charcoal.  Her main challenges in the business are seasonality and competition as many people have ventured into the same business. Mwanamkasi would like to build her own home in the future.

loans.use: To purchase 250kgs of Irish potatoes, baking flour,cooking oil, and one sack of charcoal .

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This entrepreneur is 37 years old. She is married has two children. She graduated from high school with a business degree. 

She owns a beauty salon and she needs this loan to develop her salon. Despite her small size of her shop, from its inception, she was able to attract many customers, especially brides, because she is a very good. She is so skilled at her craft that her income has risen and she has been able to hire a few women to help her. 

She has an excellent reputation in the market. Her location is so strategic that it falls in the busiest and richest part of town. Her style is so nice and mild that she has attracted more customers than other salons.

loans.use: To buy make-up and other supplies

loans.name: Daouda

texts.fr:
Né le 04 Mai 1964 à Sikasso, Monsieur Daouda  B. est polygame avec deux épouses et quatre enfants. Il réside avec sa famille dans la grande famille traditionnelle élargie à Mancourani I, le centre ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Après plusieurs années dans le métier du chauffeur, il décida il y a maintenant quatre ans de revenir  au métier familial qui est le métier de forgeron. 
Il achète des ferrailles pour en faire différentes objets (Charrues, Semoirs, Charrettes, Dabas, Marmites, etc.) qui seront vendus dans les marchés hebdomadaires des localités environnantes de Sikasso (N’Tchongobougou, Kadiolo et Hérémakono) au comptant et souvent à crédit. 
Il est beaucoup sollicité et les commandes de ses clients ne cessent d’augmenter. 
Afin de satisfaire cette clientèle de plus en plus nombreuse, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son premier  prêt qui lui permettra d’acheter, une tonne de ferraille.
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt, un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 150 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de roulement, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Born on May 4, 1964 at Sikasso, Mr. Daouda B. is polygamous, with two wives and four children. He lives with his family in a large traditional extended family in Mancourani I, the city center of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After working for several years as a driver, he decided four years ago to return to blacksmithing, the family trade. He pays in cash and often by credit for scrap iron to make various objects (ploughs, drills, carts, axes, cooking pots, etc.) which are sold in the weekly markets of Sikasso’s surrounding areas (N’Tchongobougou, Kadiolo, and Hérémakono). He is much sought after and the orders from his clients keep growing. In order to satisify this ever-growing clientele, he decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution. This is his first loan request which will enable him to buy a ton of scrap iron. With this loan, he expects to earn an average monthly profit of 150,000 CFA which will be used principally to increase his working capital, contribute to the family’s expenses and pay the interest on his loan.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy scrap iron

loans.name: Estela

texts.en: Estela P. is from the village of Batangan, Valencia City. She is 33 years old, married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Estela owns and operates a transportation service using a motorela (a motorcycle encased in a carriage with two rows of seats facing each other), with her husband as the driver, for local community members. Estela has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month from these activities. In 2010, Estela joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Estela is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide her service. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Estela from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Selling vegetables and food condiments

loans.name: Narmandah

texts.en:
Narmandah O. lives with his wife, his son and his son's family in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Narmandah's son, daughter-in-law and two grandchildren live with him in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. 

He operates and manages a traditional shoe-making business with his wife. He has been making and selling traditional shoes with white soles, called the Buriad shoe, in Narantuul -- Ulaanbaatar's largest market -- since 1998. His oldest son also produces traditional Mongolian boots and sells them at their family stalls in the market. His business is in popular spots to attract customers. 

Narmandah is a hardworking person and plans to produce more boots of different types. He is requesting a 3,000,000 Mongolian tugriks loan to grow his working capital by expanding his product line.

loans.use: To buy more materials

loans.name: God’S Blessing Group

texts.en:
Eyeah G., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called God’s Blessing. She is 55 years old and is married with five children between the ages of 15 and 33 years. She was not able to attend school due to financial difficulties.

For 25 years, Eyeah has been selling rice, biscuits, soap, liquor, etc., in Red Light Market outside of Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 10,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 43,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more rice, biscuits, soap, liquor, etc.

Eyeah describes herself as a determined woman whose goal is to build a house.

loans.use: To buy more rice, biscuits, soap, liquor, etc., to sell

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty P. is currently in the business of selling mixed goods such as cooking oil, tomatoes, etc. and is requesting a loan to improve stock. Betty is 30 years old and is married to a businessman. She has 4 children and 3 of her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy goats and invest another profits in the existing business.

loans.use: Improve stock.

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en: Lorna A. runs a sari-sari (variety retail shop) selling snacks like junk food and chicharron (fried pork rinds) and also products like vinegar and soy sauce in pouches in her community. She is 30 years old, married and has two school-aged children. They are from the village of Puerta, Lurugan, Valencia City. Lorna has been in her business for over one year and earns approximately 7,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2010, Lorna joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Lorna is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use additional income to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: My

texts.en:
Mrs. My K. is a 38-year-old married woman and a local farmer in Kompong Tom province. She uses her farmland to plant and grow rice and vegetable crops. Mrs. My K. has two children, one is single and the other works as a building worker with her husband in the construction field. She usually receives the main income from her husband and child.
Mrs. My K. is concerned about the difficulties her husband and child face in traveling to their workplace. They have to hire a taxi because they don't have their own vehicle. In order to solve this problem, Mrs. My K. has requested a loan to buy a secondhand motorcycle to provide her family with a means of transport.

loans.use: To buy a secondhand motorcycle for her family

loans.name: Vong

texts.en: Vong V., 38, lives with her husband in the Takeo province. She is a professional silk weaver, typically making 2 USD of profit a day. She has three children living at home to support. Her husband is working as a recycler collecting plastic, paper and cans. On average, he earns 3 USD each day. Vong V. needs a loan of 1100 USD to purchase a motorbike for her husband to attach to a recycle trailer.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for recycling activities

loans.name: Ramiro

texts.es:
El socio pertenece al banco comunal  “VIRGEN DEL ROSARIO DE SAN SEBASTIAN” el banco comunal está ubicado en el distrito de Huanchac perteneciente a la provincia de Cusco, departamento de Cusco.

El socio es el Sr. Ramiro; el socio tiene 42 años de edad, El socio es conviviente; el socio tiene 3 hijos; el socio en la municipalidad de Anta como chofer el socio tenía un pequeño negocio de confección de calzados, el socio ahora tiene junto a su conyugue una tienda de abarrotes, el socio desea el préstamo para poder invertir en la tienda de abarrotes y comprar mercadería nueva y de este modo implementar mas su negocio, el socio desea comprar al por mayor fideos, arroz, leche, azúcar y otros productos de primera necesidad, el socio tiene este negocio desde hace dos años. El socio solicita el préstamo para invertir en la compra de mercadería para implementar el negocio.

El socio agradece y valora el préstamo otorgado mediante este medio y del mismo modo se compromete en cumplir con el pago de su cuota en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
This member belongs to the community bank "Virgen del Rosario de San Sebastian", located in the district of Huanchac in the province and region of Cusco. 

His name is Ramiro. He is 42 years old and he lives together with his partner. He has three children. He is a driver in the municipality of Anta but he also has a shoe store. He also has a convenience store together with his wife. He wants a loan to invest in his convenience store, to purchase more inventory and with it supply his store. He wants to purchase in wholesale the following items: pasta, rice, milk, sugar and other basic products. He has had this business for the past 2 years. He requests a loan to invest in the purchase of merchandise with which to supply his business. 

He is grateful and he values the loan granted to him. He is committed to the payment terms established for his loan.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Rosa Mariana

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Portoviejo, capital de Manabí conocida desde hace muchos años  como la ciudad de los reales tamarindos, se reúnen cada quince días  las socias del Banco Comunal Mujeres En Acción.

En este lugar conocimos a la señora Rosa, tiene 50 años  de edad, es madre soltera y  tiene una hija de siete años que estudia en escuela. Vive en una casa arrendada. Hace siete años es socia del Banco Comunal y le gusta porque los créditos le han ayudado mucho con su negocio y para sacar adelante a su hija.

Tiene un pequeño  salón de belleza y en el cual realiza muchos trabajos como cortes de cabello, tinturados, maquillajes, arreglos de uñas entre otros. Trabaja de lunes a sábado de 9h00 hasta las 20h00 y a veces hasta más tarde ya que los clientes a veces necesitan trabajos más tarde y ella tiene que cumplir con los clientes.
 
Este crédito lo va invertir en comprar tintes de cabello, shampo, oxigenta, y otros materiales útiles es el arreglo personal,  Sus metas son tener un gran SPA y su casa propia.
texts.en:
In the city of Portoviejo, capital of Manabí which has been know for many years as the city of Los Reales Tamarindos (The Royal Tamarinds), the members of the community bank Mujeres en Acción (Women in Action) meet twice a month.

In this place, we met Mrs. Rosa who is 50 years old, single mother, and has a 7-year-old daughter that goes to school. She is renting a house. She has been a member of the community bank for 7 years and she likes it because the loans have helped her a lot with her business and to support her daughter.

She has a small beauty salon where she provides many services such as haircuts, hair coloring, make up, manicures and more. She works from Monday thru Saturday from 9:00 am until 8:00 pm, and sometimes later since her customers may need her services later in the day and she has to serve her customers.

She will invest this loan to buy hair dyes, shampoo, coloring agents, and other supplies for personal grooming. Her goals are to have a great Spa and own a house.

loans.use: Buy hair dyes, shampoo, coloring agents and other products for personal grooming.

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith, 53 years old, is from the town of Banga. She is married and has three children, ages 21, 19 and 16. Her children go to school and she dreams for them to have bright futures. To make a living, Judith plants and harvests corn and rice for sale.

Judith joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Judith has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 8,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) which will be used to buy seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay for her children's tuition fees.

loans.use: To buy seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Guadalupe

texts.es:
La señora Guadalupe Esperanza J. Ruiz fémina trabajadora y emprendedora quien tiene dos hijos de 18 y 15 años por los cuales labora arduamente. Ella inicio vendiendo productos Avon marca reconocida por la venta   por medio de catálogo.

 Actualmente ella invertirá en un terreno para invertir en la crianza de gallina este se localiza en granada ya que es una zona más barata que en Managua.
texts.en:
Guadalupe is a hard-working female entreprenuer who has two children, 18 and 15 years old, who also work arduously. She began by selling Avon products, a recognized brand, from the catalog.

At present, Guadalupe wishes to invest her loan in farm land for raising hens. Her farm will be located in Granada, a much less expensive zone than Managua, the capital.

loans.use: BUYING LAND TO RAISE HENS FOR MARKET

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Sok M. and her husband, Ry Rum, are farmers who own a two-hectare plot of land where they grow rice to sell to support their family. In the rice field, it is time for growing. To improve rice production, Mrs. Sok M. is asking for a loan to buy rice seed and fertilizer and to hire farming laborers to grow rice. She lives in Trapeang Leuk village, Takeo province. She supports three children, one of whom is a fisherman and two of whom attend the local public school.

loans.use: To buy rice seed and fertilize and to hire farming laborers to grow rice

loans.name: Srey's Group

texts.en:
This group loan consists of six people who live in Tep Archun village in Kandal province. 

Mrs. Srey P.  was selected to be the group leader by the other members. She was born in 1967, and she is a farmer who owns a plot of land where she cultivates rice for a living.  To support this farming, she would like a loan to buy rice seed, fertilizer, and pesticide.   Her husband, Mr. Sán An, is a homebuilder who earns a small income to support his family.  He also helps in his wife’s farming. This couple has three children: One is a car mechanic, one earns a salary in a supermarket, and the last one is a student.

loans.use: To buy rice seed, fertilizer, and pesticide

loans.name: Kmoung

texts.en:
Mrs. Kmoung, who was born in 1969, and her husband, Mr. Pich, are farmers who own a plot of land upon which they grow peanuts to earn a living. They also sell fruit juices in the local village. In order to support the farm, Kmoung is requesting a loan to hire laborers and to buy fertilizers and pesticides. She will use the rest of the loan to buy a big ice box for selling juice.

This couple has two children, one a student and the other just three years old.

loans.use: To hire farming laborers and to buy fertilizers and pesticides

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more cattle to fatten.

loans.name: 0306042 Quang Trung - Hoang Thanh - Hoang Hoa Group

texts.en:
Minh L. T. (42) is a 59-year-old woman living in the town of Hoang hoa - Thanh hoa. Minh is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 0306042 Quang Trung - Hoang Thanh - Hoang Hoa (0306042 Quang Trung - Hoang Thanh - Hoang Hoa).

Minh is married and has 3 adult -aged children. She operates a family member's business raising livestock, primarily chickens, for saL.. Minh has been engaged in this business for over 6 years and earns approximately 1,000,000 VND a month from it.

In 2004, Minh joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Minh has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000,000 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women, which was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. She is now requesting a new loan of 7,000,000 VND which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 6th loan Minh has taken out from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About the other borrowers in the group:

1.  Tham L. T. (76) is a 29-year-old woman who is requesting a 7,000,000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.

2.  Vien L. T. (63) is a 57-year-old woman who is requesting a 7,000,000 VND loan to support her fishing business.

3.  The L. T. (41) is a 54-year-old woman who is requesting a 7,000,000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.

4.  Nhung L. T. (58) is a 51-year-old woman who is requesting a 7,000,000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.

5.  Cuc L. T. (60) is a 54-year-old woman who is requesting a 7,000,000 VND loan to support her business making and selling food.

About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainabL. financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese whiL. providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Minh L. T. (42) là 59 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Hoang hoa - Thanh hoa.  Minh là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 6 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 0306042 Quang Trung - Hoang Thanh - Hoang Hoa (0306042 Quang Trung - Hoang Thanh - Hoang Hoa).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi gà để bán.  Minh thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 6 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Minh kiếm được khoảng 1,000,000 VND.  Vào 2004, Minh đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Minh đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 5,000,000 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua gia súc còn nhỏ để nuôi & bán sau này.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 7,000,000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 6th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  Tham L. T. (76) là 29 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 7000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


2.  Vien L. T. (63) là 57 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 7000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh hải sản.


3.  The L. T. (41) là 54 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 7000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


4.  Nhung L. T. (58) là 51 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 7000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


5.  Cuc L. T. (60) là 54 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 7000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ Hỗ trợ Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: to purchase more livestock

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith is a married woman with two children, all of whom attend school. She lives at a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees. 

For the past one year, she has operated a second hand clothes selling business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. Judith faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. During holiday season the demand for clothes is higher compared to the month of January to July where the demand is lower. She dreams of establishing more businesses in the future. 

With the Kshs 40,000 she is requesting, she wants to purchase two bales of second hand clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase two bales of second hand clothes for resale.

loans.name: Rosmira Elena

texts.es:
DesD. hace 28 años, Rosmira Elena Q. D. C. creó su restaurante en la Plaza D. Mercados D. Girardota, el cual ha sido la fuente D. sustentopara ella y su familia y aunque como ella misma lo afirma no viven a sus anchas por lo menos su negocio les permite comer y cubrir sus necesidades básicas.
